titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the May Day Rally and Yale Collection
May Day Rally and Yale Collection
titlestmt.author: compiled by Daniel Hartwig and the staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday March 6, 2019 at 08:26

did.unittitle: May Day Rally and Yale collection

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The materials consist of correspondence, press releases, oral history transcripts, objects, and printed material documenting Yale student involvement in the 1970 May Day rally in New Haven, Connecticut and published materials collected by the donor as a stringer for the "New York Times" related to Yale's student strike, the anti-war movement, and the Black Panthers trial in New Haven. Also included are publications related to anti-war activities nationally.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Black Panther "solidarity" shirt and silk screen banner gift of Ms. Karla Forsythe, 2013. Films of May Day activities from the New Haven Green gift of Michael Stickrod, 2016.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Forms part of Yale Record Group 41 (YRG 41), Records documenting student life.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy for their personal use should consult Copying Services information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: May Day Rally and Yale Collection (RU 86). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Yale University records are arranged and described at the accession level by the creating office. The University Archives creates collection level descriptive records, but typically does no further arrangement and description at the accession level.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: May Day weekend took place May 1-3, 1970 as a rally to protest the murder trial in New Haven of Black Panther party chairman Bobby Seale and seven other party members. Normal academic activities were suspended so that Yale students, faculty, and staff could assist in preparing the campus for the rally. Yale University opened its doors to demonstrators by offering shelter, food, day care, and first aid throughout the weekend. Approximately 15,000 people attended the first day of rallies without significant disruption or disorder. Fewer remained the following days, and academic activities resumed by Monday May 4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials consist of correspondence, press releases, oral history transcripts, objects, and printed material documenting Yale student involvement in the 1970 May Day rally in New Haven, Connecticut and published materials collected by the donor as a stringer for the "New York Times" related to Yale's student strike, the anti-war movement, and the Black Panthers trial in New Haven. Also included are publications related to anti-war activities nationally. Some posters and broadsides in Accession 1971-A-004 that were originally located in box 2 are now located in box 6.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records are arranged by accession.

odd.head: General
odd.p: 1917-M-004, box 4, folder "Miscellaneous statements and releases by community groups, New Haven Police Department, and Others" reported missing in 2016.

odd.head: General
odd.p: 1917-M-004, box 4, folder "Miscellaneous statements and releases by community groups, New Haven Police Department, and Others" reported missing in 2016.

Black Panther "solidarity" shirt and silk screen banner

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession consists of two items: a button-down shirt silk-screened on the back with the word, "Solidarity," as well as an illustration featuring the Black Panther Party logo and a bulldog; and a blue cloth banner silk screened with two Black Panther Party logos and the phrase, "POLITICAL PRISONERS OF USA FASCISM." Both the shirt and the banner were donated by Karla Forsythe, a 1971 Yale College graduate.

did.unittitle: "Political prisoners of U.S.A. fascism" silk screen banner
Letter on the Black Panther trial

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

did.unittitle: Letter on the Black Panther trial

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Unidentified typescript letter describing the events leading up to, and during the trial of the Black Panthers in New Haven.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession contains two short films that document activities from the May Day Rally that took place on the New Haven Green. The films were created by Frank Gardner, a New Haven-based film maker.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to the original film reels is restricted. Researchers must use the available digital surrogates.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Color film with no sound. Run time is two minutes and ten seconds.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Color film with no sound. Run time is eight minutes and forty-two seconds.
